body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JIMMY RICHES A Way With Women Among the firemen sifting debris at ground zero is a battalion chief, James Riches, who is searching for his son and namesake, known to his family as Little Jimmy. Jimmy Riches, who would have turned 30 on Sept. 12, is the oldest
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; One Was Almost 30, One Liked Simple Life, One Was a Born Firefighter

body: The subway cars on the W line snake from Queens through the heart of Manhattan and on to Brooklyn, collecting dirt and debris from thousands of riders. At the end of the line, on an elevated platform in sight of Coney Island's Ferris wheel, a dozen people in green vests sweep, scrape and swab the grime away. Transit-system employees doing the same
title: As Welfare Comes to an End, So Do the Jobs

body: A sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) This selection, compiled by Anne Midgette, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited her expectations. More holiday recommendations for this weekend are
title: MASSED VOICES RING OUT IN AFFIRMATION OF JOYFUL HOLIDAYS

body: Like a Kmart reimagined as ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure,'' a New York City-run warehouse in Queens is now giving away: 50,000 buttons donated by a button business; crates of neatly coiled bra straps from Victoria's Secret; rattan handbags in the shape of clam shells; and cans stacked floor to ceiling of Martha Stewart's interior decorating paint. And
title: Warehouse Holds Trove for Artists; Need 50,000 Buttons? They're Here, and Free

body: A nanny on the Upper East Side had her work schedule cut to three days a week from five because the wife in the household lost her job on Wall Street. Limousine drivers complain of carrying fewer passengers and earning 40 percent less than they did before. At many top restaurants, waiters are working just three days a week instead of five. And
title: As the Rich Do Without Extras, Service Workers Do Without

body: A Washington Heights boy hospitalized with lupus a few days shy of his graduation from fifth grade. A boy and girl from Brooklyn limited physically by a rare disease that causes a weakening of the heart. An energetic Queens toddler who looks healthy, but is fed through a tube and will need a kidney transplant one day. Two little boys in a Bronx
title: The Neediest Cases; Children's Long-Term Illnesses Mean a Strain on Families' Resources

body: THE Hilton Garden Inn on Staten Island has something that its counterparts in Manhattan lack -- outdoor space. The hotel, which opened on Sept. 15, is situated on 23 acres of land, much of it near protected wetlands, in the Bloomfield section of the western part of Staten Island. Much of the surrounding land has been developed as gardens, complete
title: Commercial Property/Staten Island; New Hilton Hopes to Become Island's Meeting Place

author: Michael Sorkin is the director of the graduate program in urban design at City College.
body: The radical act of the terrorists opens a space for us to think radically as well. While many of the billions that will be available for rebuilding -- from insurance, from federal aid, from city coffers, from developers -- are surely needed to restore the health and character of Lower Manhattan, it seems reasonable to question whether such massive
title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Boroughs]: Put a Piece of Downtown in Flushing

body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. CESAR A. MURILLO A Dance All His Own Cesar A. Murillo, 32, lived in TriBeCa and used the West Side Highway as his backyard. Along this road, Mr. Murillo used Rollerblades to get to work at Cantor Fitzgerald. He was proud of his Colombian heritage, flying a
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Doing the Lawn-Mower Dance, and Bringing a Yard Into Full Bloom

body: New York City Transit puts a lot of faith in paperwork. At times, it seems to have missed the whole computer revolution, or at least mistrusted it. In fact, in a dusty file room in downtown Brooklyn, there are boxes containing minute-by-minute records of the daily movements of your subway line, going several back years -- all handwritten, on paper.
title: Tunnel Vision; In a Simple Memo, F.Y.I., A Tense Tale of Survival

author: James Traub, a contributing writer for the magazine, writes regularly about New York politics.
body: In August, a poll appeared in this newspaper indicating that New Yorkers, a perennially discontented lot, had reached a possibly unprecedented level of contentment under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Barely a third of the respondents said that they would move out of the city if they could, down from 60 percent 10 years earlier. Only a quarter expected
title: No-Fun City

body: BOYLE-Michael. FDNY, Engine Company 33, lost his life on September 11, 2001 while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center. Michael was born on August 8, 1964 to James and Barbara Boyle in Queens, NY. Michael graduated from Westbury High School and Cortland State University. Michael was the owner of Westbury Beverage and worked for the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BOYLE, MICHAEL

body: Erica Beras nearly dismissed the e-mail message she got last weekend, about a man who was giving away thousands of books at a Downtown Brooklyn storage building. Such a giveaway seemed improbable to Ms. Beras, especially in a city in which used-book stores are cherished and book peddlers paid well. But curiosity nagged her, so last Sunday Ms.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Free Tales From Mr. Kafka's Crypt, (And Thousands of Records, Too)

body: WORKERS from the city's Human Resources Administration have played a direct role in disaster relief since Sept. 11, working extra hard to open job centers for the suddenly jobless and provide emergency social services. They have also helped in an indirect way. Three days after the attack, Mayor Giuliani, hoping to keep businesses in Lower
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; A Kind Offer Leaves Workers in Limbo

body: At first, Michael Mailer, an independent film producer, considered editing the twin towers out of his new picture, ''Empire,'' which he calls a ''Latin 'Godfather' movie'' set in New York. ''The last thing you want,'' he said, ''is something that is going to take you out of the dream of the film.'' But something about filmmakers rushing to
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN ALTERED IMAGE; The Manhattan Skyline's 'Phantom Limb'

body: THEY are the new front-line soldiers: postal workers, token clerks, baggage screeners, personal assistants and maintenance men. They are waging war in the new trenches: mailrooms, subway stations, airport lobbies, waiting rooms and ventilation sheds. Even as professional soldiers prosecute a vigorous campaign in Afghanistan and trained federal
title: The Nation; Ask Not Who Is On the Front Line

body: NATIONAL GUARDSMEN were pacing the waiting room at Grand Central Terminal. A zipper in a newsstand was reeling out an update from the F.B.I. that read like an inscription on a Barbara Kruger photograph: ''Terror could come at any time.'' And down on the concourse, time seemed to have stopped at the Oyster Bar. Sitting at one of the horseshoe-shaped
title: The Great Escape, at Vintage Tables

body: Cheese at Grand Central A tasting of Stilton cheese and port will be held today at 4 p.m. at the Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal. Admission is free. Reservations: (212) 953-0409. A Sake Evening A lecture on sake and a tasting will be held tomorrow at 6:30 p.m. at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street. Tickets, $12 for members; $15
title: CALENDAR

body: As Mark Green tried to build support among black voters yesterday in Brooklyn, the Rev. Al Sharpton called Mr. Green's campaign tactics racially divisive and hinted that he might not endorse either Mr. Green or his Republican opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg. During a rally at the National Action Network headquarters in Harlem, Mr. Sharpton and a
title: Sharpton, in Attack on Green, Hints He May Sit Out Election

body: THOUGH having long withstood the national economic doldrums, the real estate market in the New York metropolitan region was already slipping toward a slowdown by Sept. 11, housing economists and specialists say. Now the economists are wondering whether there will be a sharp V-shaped dip and rebound or a prolonged U-shaped slump. Within that
title: A Market Equation Full of Unknowns

body: The developers of two high-profile cultural projects proposed for Downtown Brooklyn are worried that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call to trim $1 billion in city spending will stall their plans, which depend partly on millions of dollars in city funding. Harvey Lichtenstein, chairman of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Local Development Corporation,
title: Brooklyn Projects' Sponsors Worry About City Cutbacks

body: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the insurance companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center, has found a new home in Midtown, becoming yet another company forced to move its big chunk of offices away from the financial district. The company signed a deal yesterday to move into three floors in a 32-story tower at 11 West 42nd
title: Empire Blue Cross Takes Space in Midtown

body: Maps tend to be pretty static things -- at least those of known lands like New York City that were long ago explored and charted and colonized with delicatessens and dry cleaners. At this late date, the chances are slim, for example, that a mountain will be discovered in Brooklyn. In Queens, 60th Place, 60th Road, 60th Avenue and 60th Street will
title: Tunnel Vision; Mapping the Movements Of a Changing Subway

body: After the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Larry Gould, a 21-year veteran planner for New York City Transit and the senior director of its operations analysis division, rushed to the agencys command center in downtown Brooklyn, where he remained, with a team of fellow planners, into the wee hours of the next morning. The challenge: come up with a way
title: Keeping the Trains Running As the Tracks Vanished

body: THE need for prime office space as a result of the destruction of 13 million square feet of office space and damage to 16.5 million more square feet in the attack on the World Trade Center has caused developers and brokers to focus attention on long-dormant development projects in Midtown and elsewhere. Douglas Durst, president of the privately
title: Office-Building Plans Come Off the Shelf

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has long been admired for his crime-fighting skills at a time when the city seemed ungovernable, and more recently for his dynamic leadership in the wake of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. But now, looking to the future, a number of urban planners and real estate executives say that Mr. Giuliani -- like
title: Some See Giuliani as Right for an Emergency, but Wrong for Rebuilding

body: In the wake of the World Trade Center attacks, questions of taste and suitability are being addressed in the art world as never before. ''People have a very heightened sense of public spaces right now,'' said Tom Eccles, director of the Public Art Fund, a nonprofit organization that presents art projects around New York City. ''One has to be
title: INSIDE ART; For Public Art, A New Scrutiny

body: LIKE other New Yorkers, the city's small Quaker community reacted to the World Trade Center attack with grief, horror, outrage and fear. But, like other pacifists, they faced an additional challenge: maintaining a strict belief in nonviolence after an act of violence had touched them so directly. ''As pacifists, we have to look as individuals
title: REVERBERATIONS; Quakers Try To Balance Patriotism And Pacifism

body: Some compared it to sneaking totalitarianism, and they asked what other unalienable rights would soon disappear. Others were not quite so upset. They simply compared it to martial law. ''Can he really do that?'' asked Tawana Brackett, gassing up her car in Brooklyn yesterday morning. ''Who says he can do that?'' They were not talking about wiretaps
title: Lone-Driver Limits Meet Mostly Road Resignation; Many Commuters Say Sacrifice Makes Sense

author: John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, is co-author of ''Place Matters: Metropolitics for the Twenty-First Century.''
body: Before Sept. 11, New York City voters were thinking about choosing the leaders of an almost wholly new government to take office on Jan. 1. They were looking for candidates who would sustain the successes of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's administration, like reducing the crime rate and welfare rolls, while tackling issues it did not successfully
title: Leadership for a Wounded City

body: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the larger tenants of the World Trade Center, is simultaneously trying to find temporary space for 1,900 workers and a permanent home, in a matter of weeks. The decision-making process is complicated not just by the speed with which it is being conducted, but also by the confusion surrounding what tax
title: For Displaced Companies, Details on City Aid Are Few

body: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 276 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 206. In all, 6,453 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives. DARREN BOHAN Banjos and Big Dreams Like so many New Yorkers, there was more to Darren Bohan than met the eye. By day he
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Lives Remembered, by the Families and Friends Who Shared Them

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: When the words ''rescue and recovery'' are heard, the people who run and repair the 722 miles of the New York City subway are not the first to come to mind. In fact, in the encomiums that have been sung about firefighters and police officers, National Guardsmen and teamsters since the work of sifting through the trade center wreckage began, subway
title: Tunnel Vision; Heavy-Duty Lifters Rushed From the Tracks to the Towers

body: Barbara Corcoran, the powerhouse Manhattan real estate broker, agreed yesterday to sell the firm she founded, the Corcoran Group, Manhattan's second-largest independent residential real estate company. The buyer is a real estate company jointly owned by the franchising conglomerate Cendant Corporation and the private investment firm Apollo
title: Corcoran Sells Realty Firm She Founded

body: SHE refuses to remove her scarf. But Efrah, a Muslim woman who lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is still afraid because she has heard stories of women in hijab (Arabic for veil) who have been attacked and called names. It was Efrah's fear that made her ask that her last name not be given in this column. She will not ride a subway or a bus. And
title: COPING; Trying to Soothe The Fears Hiding Behind the Veil

author: Deborah Sontag, a staff writer for the magazine, is the former Jerusalem bureau chief for The Times.
body: Shortly after we returned this summer from a three-year posting in Jerusalem, we borrowed a house in the woods in central Vermont. The first night, Emma and Adam, our two younger children, couldn't sleep. After learning to achieve deep slumber during the many Middle Eastern nights when tank fire pounded on the periphery of their dreams, they were
title: What Terror Keeps Teaching Us; Bringing Jerusalem Home

body: The subway trains were running downtown again yesterday. The Staten Island Ferry crisscrossed the harbor. The mayor reoccupied City Hall. But on this sunny late summer day when tens of thousands of workers returned to their Lower Manhattan offices for the first time since the World Trade Center attack, little, in fact, was normal. Commuters stood
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SCENE; Returning to the Office On the First Monday Since the City Changed

body: There will be thousands of funerals in the days to come, thousands. And grief and anger will continue to envelop those who are unable to block out one Tuesday in September, when terrorist attacks crushed a government building in Washington and reduced the storied financial towers of Manhattan to dust. Yesterday, in recognition of that aching
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE VIGILS; Surrounded by Grief, People Around the World Pause and Turn to Prayer

body: The busiest subway lines between Brooklyn and Manhattan -- some of which had been reopened on Wednesday -- were severed again yesterday, throwing millions of commuters back into turmoil that had seemed to be easing. Officials warned that getting around the New York region would not return to normal again for a long time. Commuters arrived to find
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE COMMUTERS; Closings Snarl Travel to Manhattan Again

body: In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks this week, some events may be canceled. ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue (or 35th Avenue at 36th Street), Astoria, Queens. ''Hollywood Meets the Avant-Garde,'' a weekend-long screening of early experimental films made by Hollywood directors and others.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: They came all morning, all afternoon and well into dusk, an exodus of survivors whose only way out of Manhattan was over the bridges that stretch across the East River. They walked in bewilderment and fear, some doused in ash from head to toe, some wearing surgical masks, some holding a handkerchief or a washcloth over their mouths. Some walked,
title: A DAY OF TERROR: THE RIVERS; A Battered Retreat On Bridges To the East

body: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County today. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Mayor Mark Green Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum Comptroller William
title: Primary Choices

body: The six major candidates running to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ranged across the city yesterday in the final burst of politicking before the polls open today. Dodging late summer downpours, the candidates hit neighborhoods where they thought they might be able to eek out just a few more votes. Crossing and crisscrossing the boroughs --
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR: MAYOR; Mayoral Candidates Crisscross City Seeking Last Few Votes

body: The 33rd Council District extends from the Brooklyn banks of the East River to Prospect Park, encompassing neighborhoods as varied as the city itself. It includes Greenpoint, with its enclaves of Polish and Italian families and a growing Hispanic population; a large portion of Williamsburg, the home to a large Hasidic community; downtown Brooklyn
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: NORTHWEST BROOKLYN; Five Varied Neighborhoods Test Candidates' Strategies

body: Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: About 3,000 people showed up at a job fair in Brooklyn yesterday to apply for 400 jobs as New York City school teachers, Board of Education officials said. Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the board, said the turnout for the fair was the largest that anyone could remember and twice what board officials had expected. About half of the applicants
title: Fair to Fill 400 Teacher Posts Draws 3,000

body: As New York City fans mourned her death, the body of the singer Aaliyah was flown from the Bahamas to Newark yesterday, three days after she and eight others were killed in a plane crash. Safety experts continued to examine the twin-engine Cessna propeller plane that crashed on Saturday as it was leaving Marsh Harbor in the northern Bahamas. A
title: New York Fans Grieve Over Death of Aaliyah

body: To the Editor: Getting a teaching job in New York City is no easy feat (front page, Aug. 27), but neither is leaving a teaching job. Ten years ago, I left my teaching position in a New York City public school for a higher-paying job in a suburban school system. I traveled to Court Street to resign from Board of Education employment, and after seven
title: So You Want to Teach Here . . .

body: The City Planning Commission has established a Downtown Brooklyn Special District. Delineating a downtown area where buildings up to 495 feet would be allowed and commercial activity encouraged, the commission imposed 60-to-120-foot height restrictions on new buildings in the adjacent areas of Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill. ''When viewed in the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPDATES; BROOKLYN HEIGHTS

body: A debate over a sleek 1930's building that represents a transition between Art Deco and Modernism has pitted preservationists against planners seeking to build a park along the Downtown Brooklyn waterfront. Last month a groundbreaking ceremony was held for the 1.3-acre park, which would stretch from the Manhattan Bridge past the Brooklyn Bridge to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN BRIDGE; At the Heart of a Debate, A Sleek Relic From the 30's

author: Ivy Meeropol, a granddaughter of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, is a screenwriter and journalist who lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
body: TUCKED away in the woods of southern Massachusetts, Camp Kinderland has all the trappings of a summer camp: bunks, a lake, a sports field. But the bunks have names like Joe Hill and Pablo Neruda, and the murals in the dining hall depict great moments in labor history. Kinderland was founded in 1923 by secular Jews active in the New York City trade
title: CITY LORE; The Little Red Summer Camp

body: Yesterday was a day of fear for some employees of the Board of Education headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn. Many did not know if they were targets of Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's cost-saving measures; and if they were, how they would be notified and how much time they would be given to pack their bags. But others tried to be confident about
title: Workers Left Uncertain by Schools Plan

body: The city announced a series of traffic changes for Downtown Brooklyn yesterday, all intended to make crossing the street a less harrowing experience in an area where a commercial revival has brought a huge increase in traffic that often spills over onto residential sidestreets. The dozen or so modifications, which include wider sidewalks at
title: Traffic Test Planned for Harried Downtown Brooklyn

body: Battling overcrowded schools and a rapidly dwindling construction budget, the New York City Board of Education has been in need of some bright ideas. More than a year ago, the Schoolhouse Foundation, a nonprofit group, presented one. It proposed selling bonds to build new schools without using any of the Board of Education's construction budget,
title: Budget Dispute Stalls a Plan to Build New Schools

body: SHOWING a degree of resilience in the face of the national economic slowdown, the residential real estate market in the New York metropolitan region clung to its penchant for price increases in the first half of the year, even as buyers became more choosy (or wary) and sellers lost a bit of their swagger. Though more moderate than during the frenzy
title: Home Prices Are Up, but Not as Much

body: Alan G. Hevesi backed down from his confrontation with the Campaign Finance Board yesterday, dispatching aides to negotiate with the board and pulling back from a lawsuit the mayoral candidate's political consultant had prepared to file to try to force the board to give the campaign millions of dollars in matching funds. Mr. Hevesi, the city's
title: Hevesi Backs Down on Campaign-Funds Fight

body: It was 99 degrees yesterday in Crawford, Tex., where the president is spending his summer vacation. It was 103 degrees in Glendive, Mont. And 104 in Hill City, Kan. In New York City, it was a mere 94. But it felt hotter. It always does. Could be the humidity, the pollution or the air-conditioners spewing heat onto the sidewalk. Or perhaps it is the
title: It May Be Balmy in Jamaica, But It's Blistering in Flatbush

body: Mark Green said yesterday that if he were elected mayor, his administration would be profoundly different from the current one running New York City, even within the Police Department, where he would like to shift some of the overtime budget used for crime fighting to social programs for the police and for crime prevention. Even when Mr. Green, New
title: Green Stakes Out Positions Starkly Contrasting Giuliani's

body: Following are excerpts from an interview with Mark Green, the public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor. The interview was conducted yesterday by editors and reporters of The New York Times, and it is the fifth in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates. Q. You've become familiar to New Yorkers over many years as
title: Proposing the Use of Computer Mapping to Improve School Accountability

body: For about a decade, the state and city of New York looked for a site in downtown Brooklyn for the new Kings County Family Court, the New York State Supreme Court and related city agencies. They finally found it at 330 Jay Street, across the street from MetroTech Center, the 10-block complex of commercial, educational and high-technology offices. In
title: Commercial Real Estate; For Brooklyn, a High Courthouse

body: Ten developers have submitted bids to buy the three buildings that make up the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn -- 110 and 131 Livingston Street and 65 Court Street -- and several others have expressed interest in leasing to the board a smaller building to serve as a new headquarters. The Economic Development Office, which is
title: BULLETIN BOARD; Developers Bid on Three School Board Buildings

body: A system to ease Midtown Manhattan traffic congestion by charging trucks for parking while they load and unload has been so successful that it is being expanded to a wider area, according to New York City transportation officials. They say that the system -- put in effect last November in most of the area from West 43rd to West 48th Streets between
title: Wider Area to Get Meters Limiting Truck Parking

body: IT wasn't until Michael Friedman bought a car a year or two after moving from Manhattan back to his native Brooklyn in 1981 that he remembered how his schoolteacher father, Louis, had circled the block again and again hoping to find a parking spot on the street. And after he finally found one, he hesitated to move the car from its space rather than
title: For Sale: Minimalist Condos, No View

body: WHAT is outdoor sculpture? Judging from the array of art on the streets, in the parks and plazas and at other locations in New York this summer, what isn't? Since the advent of Earthworks, Process Art and Conceptual Art in the early 1970's, outdoor sculpture has been a constantly expanding territory, and this year its borders seem more far-flung
title: ART REVIEW; Creativity Overhead, Underfoot And Even In the Air

body: SMITH STREET, Brooklyn's restaurant row, has been called the hottest new hot spot in New York. Newspapers and magazines have been filled with articles about the street in Boerum Hill, as if the strip had sat there its whole life gathering dust until the young and hip arrived a few years ago and put the place on the map. Truth be told, the 14-block
title: CITY LORE; Smith St.: A Hot Strip With a Storied Past

body: Mike Saltzstein, who for more than a quarter-century kept Coney Island's last historic carousel spinning through sunlit summers, ice-cold winters and lurching changes in the famed amusement area, died on July 4 in his Brooklyn apartment. He was 60. He apparently died of a heart attack, said his friend and partner in the carousel, James McCullough.
title: Mike Saltzstein, 60, Coney Island's Carousel Man, Dies

body: The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it would accept proposals for the development of 300,000 square feet of city-owned property at seven locations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The sites, which include lots in Washington Heights, Downtown Brooklyn, and the South Street Seaport, are suitable for commercial, industrial, or retail uses.
title: Metro Business Briefing | Forlorn Lots, Seeking Proposals

body: When Wan Shan Hu was introduced as Lafayette High School's valedictorian at graduation last month, some parents in the the audience grumbled that it was always an immigrant who got the award. Others booed outright. Unfazed, Ms. Hu finished her valedictory speech in her accented English, a shy smile the only sign of how happy she was even to be at
title: Doing Battle to Stay in High School

body: Under a punishing noontime sun, made tolerable only by a gentle breeze blowing from the river, Herman Badillo came out of his car yesterday, took off his navy suit jacket, rolled up the sleeves of his blue shirt and began walking, alone, the streets of the South Bronx. A campaign volunteer with a bullhorn walked a few steps ahead, proclaiming, in
title: In Another Bronx, Everybody Knew His Name and His Party

body: It was a day filled with parades, street fairs and large crowds, precisely the kind of day in which New York City politicians immerse themselves in the time-honored tradition of person-to-person contact. For the city's mayoral candidates, the campaign stops yesterday were an obligatory rite of summer in an election year: a Fourth of July parade in
title: Mayoral Ambitions, Paired With Tradition

body: The sky is still there. Harriet and Leonard Walit and Khay Cochran are not. On the evening of July 11, 2000, Mr. and Mrs. Walit came home and smelled gas in their town house at 420 State Street. They called their neighbor, Mr. Cochran, to help them investigate. One of the three flipped on a light switch, which apparently was the act that ignited an
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; A Jigsaw of Memories At the Site of a Fatal Blast

body: On a recent Sunday morning, the 59th Street A train platform was busier than normal for a rainy weekend. Families and a stream of rain-drenched runners, fresh from the Central Park Father's Day race, were descending the stairs when they encountered a mysterious empty subway train that roared into the station, slowed and sped up again without taking
title: Memories in Transit, On the Nostalgia Train

body: Like the rap stars she loves, Robin Williams wants her teeth to ''bling'' this summer. But since she has just your average whites, the 18-year-old has been frantically shopping for a more glamorous set, the sort that street fashionistas, from Brooklyn to the Bahamas, are snapping in and out. ''When I smile, all I want people to see is gold and ice,
title: Putting on a Front In Diamonds and Gold; Teeth Don't Mean a Thing If They Ain't Got That 'Bling'

body: There were marching bands and drum corps and a 20-piece steel drum ensemble, but the joyfullest noise of all along Surf Avenue in Coney Island yesterday emanated from the Dodger Sym-Phony, all five active survivors of it, and they brought tears to Judd Fischler's eyes. Forty-six years before, Fischler had been in another Brooklyn baseball parade, a
title: BASEBALL; It's Summer: The Boys Are Back in Town

body: To former residents of Chinatown in Manhattan, their old neighborhood is what some urban planners call an iconographic hub. On the weekends, they return in droves from their new homes, in the other boroughs and suburbs, to run errands, socialize and shop. But leaders in Chinatown say the city is slowly choking this connection, first by disrupting
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN; The Loss of a Garage Chips Away at a Hub

body: For decades, New York City struggled to arrest a long-term economic decline and prevent jobs from going to the suburbs. Today the city faces a new set of problems resulting from an improved economy: businesses that want to expand in the city but lack the space to do so. This week Senator Charles Schumer and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin
title: Helping New York Grow

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera ''FALSTAFF.'' The diminutive Amato Opera company, a fixture on the New York opera scene, ends its 53rd season this weekend with the final performances in its run of Verdi's ''Falstaff.'' Verdi's last
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: Theater ''THE BIG MOUTH MOUSE,'' a puppet show based on a Japanese fable. Tomorrow a at 2 p.m. at New Perspectives Theater Company, 750 Eighth Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. Tickets: $8; $6 for families of four or more. Information: (212) 730-2030. ''BURR FERRY,'' a reading of Linda Daugherty's play, set in 1939 rural east Texas, about a
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: A blue-ribbon panel led by Senator Charles E. Schumer is set to unveil an ambitious plan today that will call for the creation of 60 million square feet of office space over the next 20 years for 300,000 new workers. The plan calls for a combination of condemnation, tax breaks, transit links and zoning changes to create expanded business districts
title: Schumer Proposals Address Shortage of Office Space

body: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.'' Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. With a long history
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera ''FALSTAFF.'' The diminutive Amato Opera company, a fixture on the New York opera scene, is presenting the last production of its 53rd season, Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' on weekends through June 17. Verdi's last
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: Every weekday at noon, lines of hungry people descend on Luther's Fried Chicken at Jay and Willoughby Streets. Amin Ramin, the manager, said many patrons were employees at Metropolitan Transit Authority headquarters, at 370 Jay Street, which engulfs much of the block across from Luther's. For them, the restaurant is a convenient place to eat. With
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; As Whistle Blows for M.T.A., Stores Fear for Future

body: TYRONE BROWN is enjoying the way art imitates life. He is watching himself on a big movie screen set up in a schoolyard in Crown Heights. The whole neighborhood, sitting in folding chairs and on porch stoops, is turned out for the screening of ''Our Song'' on a breezy night. The film's central ensemble is a high-stepping marching band called the
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Guiding a Band in Step With a Neighborhood

body: ONE afternoon last summer I was sauntering home with a bag of vegetables when I saw something on my Brooklyn street corner that stopped me in my tracks: a red double-decker sightseeing bus and a throng of sunburned, backpack-toting tourists, chattering excitedly in some Scandinavian language. Cameras flashed and whirred. What was this all about?
title: FRUGAL TRAVELER; Playing Tourist at Home in Brooklyn

author: Adam Fifield is the author of the memoir ''A Blessing Over Ashes: The Remarkable Odyssey of My Unlikely Brother'' (Morrow).
body: WITH the urgency of a football coach scrawling plays on a blackboard, Mark Zannoni pins a diagram of subway tracks to his bulletin board, draws vigorous arrows and loops, and describes a series of tricky-sounding maneuvers. ''You can wrong-rail,'' he begins briskly, ''which is sending a train in the opposite direction of normal traffic. Then
title: CITYPEOPLE; Mapping the Perfect Detour

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, frustrated with what he considered excessive rent increases imposed last year on tenants of the city's 1 million rent-stabilized apartments, has decided to replace the chairman of the Rent Guidelines Board just as it begins debating the size of this year's increases, administration officials said yesterday. Deputy Mayor
title: Giuliani Plans To Order Shift In Rent Board

body: The sudden closing of Kozmo, the online convenience store that delivered anything from cigarettes to DVD players in less than an hour, has inflicted withdrawal pains on its loyal (some would say lazy) customers. New Yorkers are accustomed to immediate gratification, and Kozmo tapped into that, dot-com style. ''My love affair with Kozmo started
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Lost With Kozmo: Midnight Rogaine (And Doughnuts)

body: NICHOLSON * [Rating: One Star] (212) 355-6769; 323 East 58th Street (between First and Second Avenues); $$$; Review: 6/21/00. New York has a bounty of restaurants whose history is as toothsome as their menu. For instance, this charming place for nearly half a century was Cafe Nicholson, named after its creator, Johnny Nicholson, a window dresser,
title: GOOD EATING; Ask for the Plat du Jour, And You'll Get History

body: WHAT'S playing at the Roxy? Nothing, of course. Not since 1960, when demolition crews ravaged the ''Cathedral of the Motion Picture'' at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street in Manhattan and all but declared open season on movie palaces. Since then New York City has lost many of its monumental cinemas. But it has not lost them all. Some of the most
title: Xanadus Rise to a Higher Calling

body: Mark Green called yesterday for economic incentives, including changes in zoning and tax laws, to transform downtown Brooklyn into an economic hub in New York. One of four Democrats hoping to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the fall election, Mr. Green said Mr. Giuliani's economic policies had favored Manhattan and had failed to prepare the
title: Green Calls for Efforts to Make Brooklyn a Hub of City Business

body: A sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by Anne Midgette, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited her expectations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church
title: Let the Jubilant Sound of Easter Ring Out Once More

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that nearly 400 buildings inspectors would be temporarily assigned to work under the supervision of the Fire Department, as the city pushes forward with a plan to overhaul the troubled Buildings Department. The city has been seeking to break a recurring cycle of corruption at the Buildings Department, whose
title: Fire Officials Will Oversee Inspections Of Buildings

body: IT was late on a Saturday night, a few minutes shy of midnight, when Maritza Gonzalez strode through the door of Club Rio in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. She wore a black lamb's-wool coat with a mink fur collar and black leather boots elevated by four-inch heels. Visible under her coat was a black wrap blouse that revealed ample cleavage and, an inch or
title: For a New Bay Ridge, A New Tony Manero

body: WALKING TOURS ''GREENWICH VILLAGE AND SOHO: OFF THE BEATEN PATH.'' Combines tastings at local ethnic restaurants and specialty food stores with a stroll and a discussion of the history of the area. Tuesdays through Sundays at 11 a.m. Sponsored by Foods of New York. body: IT is hardly shocking that Bertha Lewis, the agitator in chief against a plan to privatize five New York City schools, started her career in the theater. Ms. Lewis, who leads the New York chapter of the scrappy community group Acorn, has spent the last two months whipping up opposition to Edison Schools, the for-profit company hoping to take over
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Agitator Turns Charm Against School Privatization

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was booed with gusto yesterday by educators packing a ballroom in Brooklyn as he called for vouchers and charter schools but not pay increases that would put New York City teachers' salaries on a par with those in the suburbs. ''Look, you don't have to agree with me,'' a rambunctious Mr. Giuliani said at one point during a
title: To Boos and Hisses, Feisty Mayor Shares His Ideas With Teachers

body: The press release had an air of grandiosity: ''Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy Hosts the First-Ever National Education Conference.'' But Mr. Levy and his aides said that was precisely the tone they meant to strike in announcing a three-day, $400,000 event that got under way yesterday at the Marriott hotel in downtown Brooklyn. About 100 officials
title: Levy Holds Event in Brooklyn To Show Off School Successes

body: SOMETIME later today, the National Invitation Tournament committee will convene, as always on college basketball's annual day of destiny, to select the remains of the tournament-bound elite. And if there is still a heart beating inside a once-grand event that celebrates the Big Apple as the core of the sport, Ron Ganulin will answer the telephone
title: Sports of The Times; Rooting for St. Francis, an Unnatural Selection

author: George Packer is the author, most recently, of ''Blood of the Liberals.''
body: In spring 1997, a wall street lawyer named Harold O. Levy was vacationing with his family on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Recently named to the New York State Board of Regents, Levy had taken along for holiday reading a data-crammed annual publication of the State Education Department known as the 655 Report. As he sat on the beach, what he read
title: The Suit

Tomorrow: two films directed by Robert Vignola, at 2 p.m., ''Enchantment'' (1921) and at 4 p.m., ''Beauty's Worth'' (1921). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Hearst's Serial Queens,''

body: To the Editor: My dad passed away in August, and I am in the midst of deciding what to to save and discard from the house I was brought up in, in Jamaica Estates, Queens. While there are loads of white elephants, there are even more memories. My dad loved telling how he saw that a building was about to be torn down in downtown Brooklyn in the late
title: To Every Item, Its Story

body: EXCEPT for that conga line of antique fire trucks chugging across every available windowsill and shelf, the commander in chief's palatial office at 9 MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn, headquarters for the 16,000-member New York City Fire Department, is as anonymous as a furniture showroom. The mighty desk is devoid of computers or spread
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Up From the Ranks and Annoying the Old Guard

body: CRITCHLOW-Mary Ellen. Of Brooklyn Heights, NY, died on Tuesday, February 27, 2001, at NYU Medical Center in New York City after a brief illness. Born on October 27, 1947, in Saratoga Springs, NY, she was the daughter of Katharine B. Donnelly of Queensbury and the late John J. Donnelly. She was a 1969 graduate of the College of New Rochelle, after
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CRITCHLOW, MARY ELLEN

body: Ray Ptomey speaks so quietly and is so modest in his manner that it is hard to imagine that he was once on anyone's hit list. But more than a decade ago he was shot five times by men who wanted him dead. He was a cocaine dealer and had knowingly stepped onto another dealer's turf. ''I was in the street,'' said Mr. Ptomey, now 47, ''doing what I
title: The Neediest Cases; Surviving Drugs' Ravages To Build a Productive Life

body: More than two centuries ago, when Brooklyn was a village surrounded by farmland and marshes, a group of Methodists began holding open-air services in what would one day be the heart of downtown. The group included whites, free blacks and former slaves, and for a couple of generations they shared the same church. But when a church building was put
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; Celebrating a Sea of Faith, Still at the Full

title: SPARE TIMES

body: On work breaks this past football season, Henry Farrell would give his tongs a rest, part company with his apron and hop the counter of the concession stand he manned at Giants Stadium. Following the roar of the crowd, he would run through a nearby corridor to root for the Jets or Giants. ''It was a great job,'' said Mr. Farrell, who lives in the
title: The Neediest Cases; Defying Labels and Low Expectations

body: THE Brooklyn Historical Society closed its headquarters building in 1999, as part of an interior reconstruction project for the landmark 1881 structure at Pierrepont and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn Heights. The society plans to reopen completely next year, but only now, after a decade of testing and analysis, do restoration professionals feel they
title: Streetscapes/Brooklyn Historical Society; An 1881 Landmark in Red Brick and Terra Cotta

body: Theater ''THE AFRICAN DRUM,'' a musical by the Shadow Box Theater celebrating African-American History Month, with actors and puppets, about a little girl who earns her supper by telling folk tales, which include ''How the Turtle Got Its Shell,'' ''How the Animals Got Their Colors'' and ''Why the Egret Flies Free.'' title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: CALL it the anti-Jersey City. New York City is proposing to change the zoning of a 37-block sector of Long Island City in Queens so it can be developed with high-rise office buildings to replace the low-rise industrial structures that dominate the area. The rezoning is likely to become effective around midyear, city officials said. The increased
title: Commercial Property/Queens; A Plan for High-Rise Offices in Long Island City

body: Last year, when a task force made up of Brooklyn community representatives considered what should be done with 18,000 square feet of state-owned parking lots in Boerum Hill, its members recommended low-rise, mixed-use buildings that would enhance and preserve the character of the landmarked residential neighborhood. But parishioners of the adjacent
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; No Parking, No Parishioners, an Orthodox Church Fears

author: Andrea Higbie is an editor in the cultural news department of The New York Times. Her last article for Arts & Leisure was about Dr. Joy Browne, the radio talk show psychologist.
body: IRWIN GONSHAK has welcomed best-selling writers like Evan Hunter (a k a Ed McBain) and Lawrence Block on ''Anything Goes!'' But what makes his stubbornly quirky radio show special is that he champions writers who are unpublished, and often unpublishable. A tax assessor spouting haikus. A retired legal secretary reciting poems about love and death.
title: TELEVISION/RADIO; A Friendly Ear For Any and All New York Writers

body: While oysters were being shucked in the kitchen, and distinguished crowds of diners from New York's business and political establishment feasted at Thomas Downing's Oyster House at the corner of Wall and Broad Streets, the proprietor's son, George, led fugitive slaves down into the basement. Amid bottles of wine and molasses, they found shelter
title: Safe Havens on the Freedom Line

body: A LANDMARK at Queens Boulevard and 56th Avenue in Elmhurst, the circular three-story-high concrete and steel building that once housed a Macy's department store and later a Stern's, is being increased in size to accommodate several large national discount stores, including a Target, a Best Buy and a DSW Shoe Warehouse. Macy's moved out of the
title: Commercial Property/Queens; Circular Building Adding 2 Floors and Big Retailers

body: Theater ''KIDS AND YIDDISH,'' an interactive musical revue by the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater, includes allusions to rap, e-mail and Austin Powers. Sundays at 11 a.m. (also Monday at 1 p.m.). title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's address last night included numerous proposals dealing with education, ranging from weekend English and science classes to the immediate construction of 12 new schools. The mayor also said he had reached an agreement with Board of Education officials to sell 110 Livingston Street, the board's headquarters in downtown
title: THE MAYOR'S ADDRESS: THE SCHOOLS; Saturday and Sunday Classes Are Proposed

body: The ambitious plan to build a $150 million shoreline park at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge took a major step forward yesterday, as Gov. George E. Pataki said the state would pay more than half its cost and donate the final piece of land needed for the project. Mr. Pataki said the state would spend $87 million to help build the 71-acre park, which
title: Long a Dream, Brooklyn Park Nears Reality
